title: List of songs written by J-Hope
text:
South Korean musician <a href="J-Hope">J-Hope</a> has written over 100 songs, including music for his career as a solo musician, band member, and songs for other performers. His debut <a href="mixtape">mixtape</a> "<a href="Hope%20World">Hope World</a>" (2018) charted in ten countries worldwide, debuting atop the <a href="Billboard%20charts%23Albums">"Billboard" World Albums</a> chart and peaking at number 30 on the <a href="Billboard%20200">"Billboard" 200</a>, the highest peak by a Korean soloist at the time of release. J-Hope collaborated with numerous <a href="Big%20Hit%20Entertainment%23Producers">in-house producers</a> at his record label <a href="Big%20Hit%20Music">Big Hit Entertainment</a> to create the mixtape and is a credited writer on all seven tracks. The mixtape's lead single "Daydream", which debuted at number one on the <a href="Billboard%20charts%23International%20charts">"Billboard" World Digital Song Sales</a> chart, is a <a href="house%20music">house</a> track discussing J-Hope's struggles as a <a href="Korean%20idol">Korean idol</a> presented in an upbeat style. J-Hope conceptualized the song as a means to discuss "the desires and wishes that every person in the world has but [he has] to hold down and cover up" due to his career path. He later released his second solo work in September 2019, a <a href="single%20%28music%29">single</a> entitled "<a href="Chicken%20Noodle%20Soup%20%28J-Hope%20song%29">Chicken Noodle Soup</a>" featuring American singer <a href="Becky%20G">Becky G</a>. The song contains lyrics about J-Hope's background in dance, and is performed in three languages: Korean, English, and Spanish. The song peaked at number 81 on the <a href="Billboard%20Hot%20100">"Billboard" Hot 100</a>, marking the first time a member of BTS has appeared on the chart as a soloist.
He serves as one of the primary songwriters for the <a href="pop%20music">pop</a> and <a href="hip%20hop">hip hop</a> <a href="boy%20band">boy band</a> <a href="BTS%20%28band%29">BTS</a>, of which he is a member, appearing as a credited writer on every album released by the group since their debut in 2013. On these albums he primarily works with the Big Hit production team, including company founder <a href="Bang%20Si-hyuk">Bang Si-hyuk</a>, and fellow BTS rappers <a href="RM%20%28rapper%29">RM</a> and <a href="Suga%20%28rapper%29">Suga</a>. The trio later collaborated to release the <a href="trap%20music">trap</a> <a href="diss%20%28music%29">diss track</a> "Ddaeng", produced by Suga and Korean record producer Jang Yi-jeong and inspired by traditional Korean instrumentals. He has also penned music for other musical endeavors by BTS members, co-writing the song "Otsukare" by the duo Sope, made up of him and Suga. In addition, J-Hope composed much of the melody for the 2016 ballad "Awake", performed by BTS vocalist <a href="Kim%20Seok-jin">Jin</a> as his first solo song.
J-Hope's work as a writer for musicians outside of BTS has been minimal. In 2012, before his official public debut, J-Hope featured on the track "Animal" by former labelmate <a href="Jo%20Kwon">Jo Kwon</a>. He also participated in the writing team, which included Swedish <a href="Electronic%20dance%20music">EDM</a> producer <a href="Avicii">Avicii</a>. He also worked with South Korean music pioneer <a href="Seo%20Taiji">Seo Taiji</a> to adjust portions of the track "Come Back Home" from the album "<a href="Seo%20Taiji%20and%20Boys%20IV">Seo Taiji and Boys IV</a>" (1995). The track was eventually performed by BTS at the Seo Taiji 25th Anniversary concert in August 2017.
